p.seg: Nebraska Public Library Commission Bulletin Vol. 1 Lincoln, Nebraska, January, 1931 No. 1 published quarterly for free distribution Application for entry as second-class matter i~ pending NEBRASKA PUBLIC LIBRARY COMMISSION EDITH TOBITT, Chairman Omaha, Nebraska E. A. BURNETT Chancellor of the University of Nebraska GILBERT H. DOANE , Librarian of the University of Nebraska CHARLES B. LETTON State Librarian CHARLES W. TAYLOR State Superintendent of Public Instruction NELLIE WILLIAMS, Secretary TABLE OF CONTEXTS . The Fifteenth Biennial Report of the Commission

LETTER •>!■• TRANSMITTAL Honorable Arthur J. Weaver, Governor of Xebraska: Dear Sir: Complying with the requirements bl the law, I herewith presenl the secretary's report of the Nebraska Public Library Commission 'for the biennium ending N'ovember 30. 1930. Respectfully yours. EDITH TOBITT. Chairman

NEBRASKA PUBLIC LIBRARY COMMISSION Secretary's Report . December 1. 1928 to November 30, 1030 THE COMMISSION There h.-i> been one change on the staff of the Commission during the last, bienh.ium. Marguerite Ne'shit resigned her. position to take effect in .July. l'.'iSo. She had been with tho Commission since 1021, as clerk for traveling libraries and later as reference librarian. In l!*2iS, she" was authorized by the Commission to assist in the field Work. Tho Commission and the state owe much to Miss Xesbit for the service 'rendered by her- during tho years of 'her association with this department. She is now acting librarian for Doane College, at Crete, Nebraska. The position left vacant by Miss Xosbit's resignation is now held by Dorothy- 'Woodrow, of Chicago, Illinois. .Miss Woodrow secured her degree in library science at the University of Michigan in 1HS0. Edna Booth, in. charge of the traveling libraries since 1U25, was married in June, 1930, to Dr. H. Armin I'agel, of the faculty of Nebraska University: Mrs. Pagel continues as clerk for traveling libraries.' Xaomi Henry acts as stenographer. ACTIVITIES The work of the Commission is divided into three activities: assist - ance in organizing' libraries, a system of loans, and the supervision of libraries in the state institutions- under the Board of Control. . FIELD WORK The tield work of the Commission consists of visits to towns having libraries and to towns about to establish them. It has'always been the aim of the Commission, in fulfilment of what it considers the law regarding it, to visit periodically all public libraries and to answer as rapidly as possible all specific calls for help. In addition to the requests from public libraries there is a growing number of calls for assistance in organizing school libraries. It is a rather far cry from this aim of the Commissoin to its ful - filment, for the field work has been materially hindered since July, 192!(. Curtailment of library visits is due to a decrease in that part of the Commission appropriation which includes the travel fund. A cut of 25 per cent from an amount already inadequate has made retrenchment of all maintenance expenditure necessary. This has been difficult because of constantly increasing requests. LOANS During the biennial period covered by this report, books have been sent into each of the ninety-three counties of Nebraska. Approxi - mately (i00 communities have been served. Books belonging to the Commission are provided for the citizens of the state and are presumably' not to be loaned to those of other states. Requests from states having a similar service are referred to their 3

respective Library Commissions. However, for reasons of courtesy or specific need, some loans are made outside Nebraska.' During the past two years the Commission has sent books into the following states- Arizona, Colorado, Illinois, Indiana, lowa, Kansas, Maine, Michigan! Minnesota, M.ssouri, New York, Ohio, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, South Dakota, Oregon, Wisconsin and Wyoming:. One loan was made to Alaska. The following is a classified arrangement of the requests and loans from December 1, 1928 to November 30, 1930: Borrowers Requests Volumes uroups of residents ggg ->4 "o's Public libraries -ZZZZZZZ.. 611 i0'059 School and college libraries • i in Ki'inr stndycubs..... I:::::::::::::;:;;: !:JS..- g S;J?B Other organizations j,, 104'" Individuals I:.""!""!';" 7,339 2:i',718 Total - 10,644 136,610 TRAVELING LIISKAUrES As shown in the classified loans, traveling libraries are sent to groups of residents, public libraries, schools and other organizations The total number of traveling library loans from December 1 19*8 to November 30, 1930. was 106.867, of which 63,105 volumes were sent to schools. REFEIiKNCK LOANS The reference librarian has filled requests for 8. .".18 individuals during the past biennium by the loan of books, magazines, pamphlet* or clippings as the case might require. The persons served are from all the counties of the state. These special loans are sent by parcel, post which since Julv l<r»i is a very low rate. By act of Congress under Section. 444% libfarv books may be sent within the state for 3 cents for the first pound and 1 cent for each additional pound. Some borrowers have reported that local postmasters are not allowing them the advantage of this rate It applies to the individual returning the books as well a< to the Com - mission or any other library sending them out. f 1n ., 19 !, 3 th e Library Commission began to do the reference work tor the Extension Department of the University. The work grew to such an extent and encroached so much upon the time of the refer - ence hbranan, that the Commission decided it inadvisable to continue the service. It was accordingly discontinued July 1, 1930. INSTITUTIONAL LIBRARIES Since 1911 the Commission has had an appropriation for providing books and library service for those confined in the Nebraska insti - utions in charge of the Board of Control. Year by vear book co - lections have been building in each of fifteen institutions, for the use of those so confined. The biennial record of 81,822 books loaned is evidence that reading is a definite part of the day's schedule 4

PUBLICITY The Commission lias heretofore had no means of publicity. Realiz - ing the need of more frequent communication with the libraries of the state, it was decided by the Commission, on November 26, 1930, to publish a quarterly bulletin. This report is the first issue of the bulletin. PUBLIC LIBRARIES The number of Nebraska public libraries is 140. College View and Havelock. listed in former reports, are now by annexation a part of the Lincoln city library. Adams and Imperial have been added dur - ing the biennium, making the total number of municipal libraries the same as two years ago. The towns of Milford and Wilber have also organized libraries. Both give promise of becoming municipal libraries this year.
